name: 5,6-dimethylchrysene
Reason: 5,6-dimethylchrysene has a melting point that is influenced by its structural components relative to the base melting point of benzene, which is around 5°C. The basic unit for comparison is chrysene, which has a melting point of 106.5°C. The methyl groups (5,6-dimethylchrysene) add approximately +10°C due to the increase in molecular weight and rigidity of the structure. The chrysene ring itself contributes to the melting point due to its planarity and rigidity, estimated at around +20°C. The methyl groups also increase the melting point due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5°C.
